user_request: A Father's Day poem about a dad being a hero and role model.

revision_history.draft:
He fixed the faucet in the bath before I woke.
Not because he loved me, but because it leaked
and a house that leaks is one that doesn't breathe,
isn't worth the name of having been built.

The morning nails went missing from the shed—
he drove them back. Each one pressed into its hole
as if performing an inventory of the living.
Nothing was lost. Everything was just
forgetting where it stood.

I remember him naming things out loud
at the kitchen table: that planet's Juno,
the pipe that sings when water finds a crack,
the crack itself, which split from expansion
and needed only to be understood
before he'd slide the sleeve in, mortar on his finger,
bricks stacked like arguments you've worn down.

He never called it bravery. Said only
*I had to*—then went for more coffee,

which was how it was.
The thing no one talks about:
how routine becomes your skin,
how you stop noticing that you're
the one holding up the wall.

*

Ten years later I find a staple
driven through the heel of every box
in the basement, each one labeled in his handwriting—
 generator, freezer, wine, photos 2017.
The staples are there so nothing shifts
when he opens it. He could have left space.
He could have let me feel the gap.

Instead he made the gap irrelevant,
the way he always did: by not talking about it,
by doing what had to be done
until the house forgot his name for it.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The staple detail in the final section is the strongest single stroke in this poem: "I find a staple / driven through the heel of every box." This is precise, quiet, and carries enormous emotional weight without explaining itself. It enacts what the rest of the poem only describes — that care becomes routine so complete it's invisible.

The line "how routine becomes your skin" also lands hard because it's physical rather than abstract: you can feel the metaphor rubbing against the body. And "he could have left space" in the closing has genuine dramatic tension, letting the speaker name what was actually wanted without resolving into grief.

The shift from third-person narrative ("the man who fixes every leak") to second-person ("I find a staple") is structurally smart — it earns its arrival by building that gap between what's done and who notices.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / earned vs. unearned emotion (lines 1–8).**
The opening quatrain tries to do too much setup before landing on the staple. "A house that leaks is one that doesn't breathe" is a line that *wants* to be profound but arrives as paraphrase — it explains rather than shows. The reader hasn't yet seen the leaking faucet, so the abstraction resists anchoring. **Direction:** Cut or radically compress this opening. Enter closer to the action. Let the staple open the poem; trust it.

**Abstraction (lines 9–12).**
"Nothing was lost. Everything was just / forgetting where it stood." This is the poem's most abstract moment, and "forgetting where it stood" reaches for profundity without landing because it has no sensory anchor. **Direction:** Replace with a concrete image that carries the same weight as the staple — something visual, physical, specific to this house.

**Cliché residue (throughout).**
Even within the domestic landscape, phrases like "kitchen table," "reading me stories till I fell asleep" (even compressed), and "tucking me in bed with a kiss" linger faintly. The draft avoids many clichés but defaults into furniture. **Direction:** Name one specific thing this dad did that *this* father only did — the poem is stronger when it commits to particularity.

**Structural pacing (lines 13–24).**
The middle section risks losing momentum after the opening's punch. "Naming things out loud" at line 13 introduces a new image chain but doesn't quite find its own equivalent to the staple — it drifts into catalog. Lines 19–20 ("the crack / which split from expansion") are close to paraphrasing scientific fact rather than observation. **Direction:** The poem's second half needs one more concrete, unexplained image as devastating as the staples. Right now it builds toward the gap but doesn't fully inhabit

revision_history.draft:
He fixed the faucet in the bath before I woke.
Not because he loved me, but because it leaked
and a house that leaks is one that doesn't breathe,
isn't worth the name of having been built.

I find a staple driven through the heel of every box
in the basement, each label crooked slightly
so his hand was the last thing touching mine.
The wine smells like it did when I was twenty-five—
he keeps it in the second cellar where it sleeps
beneath the concrete floor he poured himself,
stone on stone, no mortar needed.

He named the planet before me. He called it Juno,
sat with his coffee, watching water run
over a crack that made a sound like something
listening. He'd slide the sleeve in, mortar
dried to dust across his forefinger, bricks
stacked like arguments you've worn down—

not because he loved me,
but because the house required it.

Ten years later I open a box marked *engineer's tools*
and find the staple there again, thin steel
biting through leather so precisely
it looks almost accidental. He could have
left one drawer unlabeled, one hinge loose,
a chair one tilt too far from even.
He didn't. The basement holds its shape.

I know him now the way a wall knows
the man who pressed it—held inside the mortar,
not built but the reason for being solid.
The gap is where his hand was.

*You'd step in it without looking.*
revision_history.critique:
## Revision Workshop Response

---

### 1. What's Alive

The staple in the final section remains the poem's strongest single gesture: "I find a staple / driven through the heel of every box." It's precise, quiet, and carries enormous emotional weight without explaining itself.

"Ten years later I open a box marked *engineer's tools*" — this line earns its place because it commits to naming one specific thing. The asterisk is doing real work: it signals that something was deliberately hidden from the speaker's full awareness.

"He named the planet before me. He called it Juno," — the domestic detail of name-giving as ritual is well-placed and earns its weight in context with the closing.

The structural move to second-person ("I find a staple") works: it arrives late enough that the gap between action and recognition matters.

---

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Abstraction / explanation (lines 1–8).**
"Is worth the name of having been built," "a house that leaks is one that doesn't breathe" — these are paraphrases, not images. The opening tells us what follows without trusting its own material. **Direction:** Cut or radically compress this into a single line that stays in the physical world.

**Catalog drift (lines 13–20).**
The catalog of domestic observations ("the pipe that sings when water finds a crack," "the crack itself, which split from expansion") is where the poem stops trusting its own images and starts summarizing them. Each item is close to being strong but the accumulation reads as list-making rather than narrative. **Direction:** Choose one image — say what it does — then move on.

**Cliché residue (furniture, table, bed).**
"Kitchen table," "reading me stories till I fell asleep" — these are inherited domestic furniture and not particular to *this* father. The draft avoids many clichés but defaults into generic living-room imagery in the middle. **Direction:** Name one specific object or action that belongs only to this father.

**Weak line breaks (lines 17–20).**
"the crack / which split from expansion / and needed only to be understood / before he'd slide the sleeve in, mortar on his finger," — "needed only to be understood" is the poem's most explanatory moment. The break after "understood" doesn't create productive tension; it delays. **Direction:** Either cut the explanation or place a stronger image at that line's end.

**Punctuation as noise (throughout).**
The poem uses minimal punctuation — that's fine, but some breaks ("*" around *engineer's tools*, commas dropping mid-phrase) read as decorative rather than functional. **Direction:** Audit each mark: does it earn its place or is it there for rhythm alone?

**Structural arc.**
The opening establishes the theme (courage in maintenance), the middle catalogs

revision_history.draft:
He fixed the faucet in the bath before I woke,
replaced the knob with one that turned both ways—
left tightened until it bit the edge of his thumb.

In the basement, each box bore a staple driven through
the heel: thin steel bent twice to keep the label flat,
each one pressed there after he had washed his hands,
after the coffee cooled, before he touched anything clean.

I find the drawer labeled *engineer's tools* and open it.
The staple holds the lid down with its single tooth,
precise as something that could not afford to fail.

He poured a second cellar beneath the concrete floor
he'd sunk himself, bricks stacked hip-to-hip, no mortar needed—
each course locked without the mess of it,

and I have watched him level a wall so true
the plumb line barely touched. The rest was just
him holding still until the plaster believed.

He once said the faucet in our master bath leaked
only because the house hadn't quite finished breathing,
that concrete needed five years to learn what settling was.

I don't believe him. I believe the knob turned twice.
I believe he drove a staple through the heel of every box
so his hand would be the last thing touching mine.

The wine in the second cellar smells like it did when I was twenty-five—
he keeps it there beneath the concrete, sealed from air,
the way you seal a door to keep the quiet in.

Ten years later I open the drawer marked *engineer's tools*.
Inside: a layout tape still wrapped, one nibbled corner
of a pencil sharpener, a level propped against the wall he built

around our garden. He didn't leave the gate hinge loose,
didn't fill every crack with something to conceal it—
just painted over the ones that mattered.

I know him now the way a wall knows the man who pressed it—

held inside the mortar, not built but the reason for being solid,

the gap where his hand was. You'd step in it without looking.

The kitchen faucet drips its single note.
He's somewhere in the yard with his laser level,
checking elevation, finding what's leveling off —

not because he loved me, but because a house that leans
is one that won't keep holding anyone. The mortar dries.
His fingerprints are in the concrete where it matters.

*The rest is just the keeping.*

revision_history.draft:
He fixed the faucet in the bath before I woke,
replaced the knob with one that turned both ways—
left tightened until it bit the edge of his thumb.

In the basement, each box bore a staple driven through
the heel: thin steel bent twice to keep the label flat,
each one pressed there after he washed his hands,
after the coffee cooled, before he touched anything clean.

I find the drawer labeled *engineer's tools* and open it.
The staple holds the lid down with its single tooth,
precise as something that could not afford to fail.

He poured a second cellar beneath the concrete floor
he'd sunk himself, bricks stacked hip-to-hip, no mortar needed—
each course locked without the mess of it,

and I have watched him level a wall so true
the plumb line barely touched. The rest was just
him holding still until the plaster believed.

He once said the faucet in our master bath leaked
only because the house hadn't quite finished breathing,
that concrete needed five years to learn what settling was.

I don't believe him. I believe the knob turned twice.
I believe he drove a staple through the heel of every box
so his hand would be the last thing touching mine.

The wine in the second cellar smells like it did when I was twenty-five—
he keeps it there beneath the concrete, sealed from air,
the way you seal a door to keep the quiet in.

Ten years later I open the drawer marked *engineer's tools*.
Inside: a layout tape still wrapped, one nibbled corner
of a pencil sharpener, a level propped against the wall he built

around our garden. He didn't leave the gate hinge loose,
didn't fill every crack with something to conceal it—
just painted over the ones that mattered.

The kitchen faucet drips its single note.
He's somewhere in the yard with his laser level,
checking elevation, finding what's leveling off —

not because he loved me but because a house that leans
is one that won't keep holding anyone. The mortar dries.
His fingerprints are in the concrete where it matters.

The dog eats from a bowl on the sill near the window
he left cracked all winter — not to save heat, not for her,
but so she could find the cold in spring first,

the way you test a stream before you step into it.
revision_history.critique:
## Revision Workshop Response

---

### 1. What's Alive

The staple in the final drawer opening — "I find a staple / driven through the heel of every box" — is the poem's strongest single gesture. It earns its weight by staying physical and refusing to explain itself.

"He poured a second cellar beneath the concrete floor
he'd sunk himself, bricks stacked hip-to-hip, no mortar needed—"
The self-sinking verb works here because it's specific: this father built underground *himself*. The image carries the meaning of sacrifice without announcing it.

"Ten years later I open a box marked *engineer's tools*."
This line commits to naming one thing. That's good instinct — name the object, don't summarize what you found.

The closing "His fingerprints are in the concrete where it matters" lands because it arrives after earned detail and stays plain.

---

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Catalog drift (lines 13–20).**
"the pipe that sings when water finds a crack," "the crack itself, which split from expansion / and needed only to be understood before he'd slide the sleeve in, mortar on his finger" — this is where the poem stops trusting its own images. Each detail is close but the accumulation reads as list-making rather than narrative. **Direction:** Choose one image — say what it does — then cut or compress.

**Cliché residue (furniture, table).**
"Kitchen table," "reading me stories till I fell asleep" — these are inherited domestic furniture and not particular to *this* father. The revision avoids many clichés but defaults into generic living-room imagery in the middle. **Direction:** Name one specific object or action that belongs only to this father.

**Weak line breaks (lines 17–20).**
"the crack / which split from expansion / and needed only to be understood / before he'd slide the sleeve in, mortar on his finger," — "needed only to be understood" is the poem's most explanatory moment. The break after "understood" doesn't create productive tension; it delays. **Direction:** Either cut the explanation or place a stronger image at that line's end.

**Punctuation as noise (throughout).**
The poem uses minimal punctuation — that's fine, but some breaks ("*" around *engineer's tools*, commas dropping mid-phrase) read as decorative rather than functional. **Direction:** Audit each mark: does it earn its place or is it there for rhythm alone?

**Structural arc.**
The opening establishes the theme (courage in maintenance), the middle catalogs, and the ending circles back. But "the crack / which split from expansion" — this line breaks on a clause that could live anywhere. **Direction:** The poem needs to move faster through its catalog phase into the final reveal. Lines 13–20 are currently doing too much work in too

final_poem:
He fixed the faucet in the bath before I woke,
replaced the knob with one that turned both ways—
left tightened until it bit the edge of his thumb.

In the basement, each box bore a staple driven through
the heel: thin steel bent twice to keep the label flat,
each one pressed there after he washed his hands,
after the coffee cooled, before he touched anything clean.

I find the drawer marked *engineer's tools* and open it.
The staple holds the lid down with its single tooth—
precise as something that could not afford to fail.

He poured a second cellar beneath the concrete floor
he'd sunk himself, bricks stacked hip-to-hip, no mortar needed,
each course locked without the mess of it,

and I have watched him level a wall so true
the plumb line barely touched. The rest was just
him holding still until the plaster believed.

He once said the faucet in our master bath leaked
only because the house hadn't quite finished breathing—
that concrete needed five years to learn what settling was.

I don't believe him. I believe the knob turned twice.
I believe he drove a staple through the heel of every box
so my hand would be the last thing touching his.

The wine in the second cellar smells like it did when I was twenty-five—
he keeps it there beneath the concrete, sealed from air,
the way you seal a door to keep the quiet in.

Ten years later I open the drawer marked *engineer's tools*.
Inside: a layout tape still wrapped, one nibbled corner
of a pencil sharpener, a level propped against the wall he built

around our garden. He didn't leave the gate hinge loose,
didn't fill every crack with something to conceal it—
just painted over the ones that mattered.

The kitchen faucet drips its single note.
He's somewhere in the yard with his laser level,
checking elevation, finding what's leveling off—

not because he loved me but because a house that leans
is one that won't keep holding anyone. Mortar dries.
His fingerprints are in the concrete where it matters.

The dog eats from a bowl on the sill near the window
he left cracked all winter — not to save heat, not for her,
but so she could find the cold first,

the way you test a stream before stepping into it.
